The patient is a 25-year-old female presenting with the "worst headache of her life," which started suddenly yesterday, July 31st, at 11 AM. Associated symptoms include blurry vision, lightheadedness described as "blind spots," and difficulty writing (writing looks "messy" and "like I am trying with my left" despite being naturally right-handed). She also reports facial swelling that started around the same time as the headache. She denies vomiting. The doctor plans a thorough exam and evaluation, CT scan, migraine cocktail, and Morphine.

The patient is a 25-year-old female presenting with the "worst headache of her life" which started suddenly yesterday, July 31st, at 08:00. Associated symptoms include blurry vision, lightheadedness described as blind spots, difficulty writing (messy, like writing with her left hand despite being right-handed), and facial swelling that started around the same time as the headache. She denies vomiting. The emergency physician plans a thorough exam and evaluation, CT scan, and will administer a migraine cocktail and Morphine.

The patient is a 90-year-old female presenting for a follow-up visit. She reports that her high blood pressure and right arm symptoms are basically gone. Her blood pressure is much better, but she did not tolerate a higher dose of Mavik and returned to her previous dose of 1mg/day. She suspects white coat hypertension, but her daughter confirms home blood pressure readings are consistently similar to office readings. She was offered Tarka but found the pills too large. Her right arm pain is resolved, attributed to a muscle problem in her right shoulder blade. X-rays of the neck and right shoulder show degenerative changes and a possible rotator cuff injury (high humeral head in glenoid), but the patient denies any pain in that area. She reports new stomach pain, which has improved since she stopped taking Aleve, and she now uses Tylenol as needed. She also takes Tums three times a day and Mylanta at night, but denies acid reflux or heartburn. She has recurrent mouth sores that come and go, and has worn dentures for many years. She also reports tremors in her upper body (torso and arms) since starting Lexapro, though the doctor notes it is hard to tell if she has a tremor today. She believes the Lexapro is otherwise helping.

The patient is a 90-year-old female presenting for a follow-up. Her high blood pressure has improved, but she discontinued the higher dose of Mavik due to feeling unwell and returned to 1mg daily. Her daughter confirms home blood pressure readings are consistent with clinic readings. The patient was offered Tarka but stated the pills were too big. Her right arm pain has resolved and was attributed to a muscle problem in her right shoulder blade. X-rays of the neck and right shoulder show degenerative changes and possible rotator cuff injury (high humeral head), but the patient denies pain in this area. She reports new stomach pain, which has improved since stopping Aleve, and she is now taking Tylenol as needed. She denies acid reflux but takes Tums three times daily and Mylanta at night. She also reports recurrent mouth sores, which come and go, associated with long-term denture use. Additionally, she experiences tremors in her upper body (torso and arms) since starting Lexapro, though she finds Lexapro otherwise helpful.

The patient is a 90-year-old female presenting for follow-up. She suspects white coat hypertension, and her daughter confirms home blood pressure readings are similar to clinic readings. Right arm symptoms are basically gone, attributed to a muscle problem in the right shoulder blade. X-rays of the neck and right shoulder show degenerative changes and possible rotator cuff injury (high humeral head in glenoid), but the patient denies pain in this area. She reports stomach pain that has improved since stopping Aleve, currently managed with Tylenol as needed, Tums 3x/day, and Mylanta at night. She denies acid reflux or heartburn. She also has recurrent mouth sores, which heal and reappear, and has worn dentures for many years. Since starting Lexapro, she experiences tremors in her upper body (torso and arms), though she and her family feel the Lexapro is otherwise helpful.

The 90-year-old patient is currently taking Mavik 1mg daily for hypertension, having reverted to this dose from a higher one due to not feeling well. She was offered Tarka (trandolapril/verapamil) but refused due to pill size. She takes Tylenol as needed, Tums three times daily, and Mylanta at night for stomach pain, which improved after discontinuing Aleve. She also takes Lexapro, and reports new tremors in her upper body, torso, and arms since starting it.

The patient, turning 90 this month, presents for follow-up reporting resolution of her high blood pressure and right arm symptoms. She is not taking the prescribed higher dose of Mavik due to intolerance, having reverted to 1mg daily, and suspects white coat hypertension, though her daughter confirms similar home blood pressure readings. She was offered Tarka, a combined medication, but states the pills are too big to take. Her right arm pain has resolved, which she attributes to a muscle problem in her right shoulder blade. X-rays of the neck and right shoulder today show degenerative changes and a possible rotator cuff injury (high humeral head in glenoid), but the patient denies any pain in this area. New complaints include stomach pain, which has improved since stopping Aleve, and she now uses Tylenol as needed, Tums three times daily, and Mylanta at night. She also reports recurrent mouth sores, which come and go, and has worn dentures for many years. Additionally, she experiences tremors in her upper body (torso and arms) since starting Lexapro, though she finds Lexapro otherwise helpful and the doctor finds the tremor difficult to observe today.

The patient is a 90-year-old female presenting for follow-up, reporting that her high blood pressure and right arm symptoms have resolved. She did not tolerate a higher dose of Mavik and reverted to her previous dose of 1mg daily. Her daughter confirms that home blood pressure readings are similar to office readings. The patient was offered Tarka but stated the pills were too large. Her right arm pain is gone, which she attributes to a muscle problem in her right shoulder blade. X-rays of the neck and right shoulder show degenerative changes and a possible rotator cuff injury based on a high humeral head in the glenoid, but the patient denies any pain in this area. She reports new stomach pain, which has improved since she stopped taking Aleve. She now uses Tylenol as needed, Tums three times a day, and Mylanta at night, though she denies acid reflux. She also has recurrent mouth sores in the setting of long-term denture use. Since starting Lexapro, she has experienced tremors in her upper body, torso, and arms, but reports the medication is otherwise helpful.

The patient is a 29-year-old male presenting with right shoulder pain which started on June 3, 2004. The pain began after he heard a pop while picking up a stack of cardboard, putting it down, and twisting to the right, sometimes throwing items lifted to waist level. He describes the pain as being in the lateral part of the back of his right shoulder and reports an inability to lift heavy items and a loss of strength since the incident. He also has a history of losing an arm due to a motorcycle accident.

The patient is a 24-year-old male presenting with rashes on his chest, legs, arms, and back, which he attributes to poison ivy exposure during a fishing trip this weekend. He states this has happened "several times before" and previously received an 80mg Depo-Medrol injection from Dr. Blackman, which "worked fine" but took time to resolve. This time, he has been self-treating with over-the-counter Benadryl and cortisone cream, noting "a little bit of improvement," but reports the rashes "seemed to have been worst" this weekend. The plan is for another injection.
